We have had our differences on a few threads here, I believe in a persons right to choose, and I believe that each person has to live with the consequences of those actions. Do I think some of those choices are right, NO, but I defend their right to make them as they see fit, as long as they are within the law. In this case in Ontario (and appears to be in some states in the US too) this is the law, but why? Seems to me to be just some feel good legislation to another perceived problem, and like another poster pointed out, it's ok for the 16 yr old to smoke but not the adult in the car??? BTW, I don't smoke, and do I think the example you are providing is one in which some really poor choices are being made for the sake of those children involved, YES. If you want to protect the children from their parents smoking then we should ban the smoking everywhere, that would make more sense, pass that law.

In Ontario we have free health care. We also know that smoking is harmful long term as is second hand smoke for non smokers. We also know that smoking, nursing mothers have infants that are addicted to nicotine thru breast milk. That said, I believe our Gov't and law makers are being pro-active and looking long term into the effects of nicotine on health care. If there are fewer smokers today then there will likely be fewer cases of smoking related cancers, asythma, etc in the hospital beds 20, 40, and 60 years from now.
